As a fan of the first two games in this series, I am disappointed. You can't import your character as expected because of the entirely reworked skill tree and class system. The skill trees have been significantly dumbed down, many abilities are gone, auras are pointless, and each class now only has one combat style with no more switching between ranged and melee combat. Level cap reduced down to 30, Katarina's is 25. No starting on veteran mode with an imported character.

The game has its fair share of bugs too. The controller profile does not allow you to access all parts of the character creation panel, nor can it access the bonuses in the skill tree when leveling up. I've also encountered a game-breaking bug preventing progress in Valley of Frost due to my character constantly falling through the floor.

Bugs aside, this could be a decent ARPG title for ~$12, but it's not a very good Van Helsing sequel.

edit: Latest patch has addressed the falling through the map glitch. I'm not sure if the controller scheme issues have been fixed since I progressed through the game with mouse and keyboard instead. The game is less than 10 hours long. Glory points seem to be broken, so there is literally no point to importing a character at all, since those were the only things that would carry over. Multiple achievements are still broken, like reaching level 30 with a certain class, hitting an enemy over 1K damage, being hit for 1K damage, etc. There is a tower defense quest that still cannot be turned in. Even if Neocore fixes all these bugs, it still remains a really poor finale to what was once a great series.

Well, I bought as a gesture of loyalty having previously enjoyed the first two Van Helsing games.

These are my first impressions after playing through the first dungeon with each of the classes. Unfortunately they are mostly negative.

- At the moment I cannot import my hero - who travelled through the first two games - even though this is a direct continuation of the plot.
- You now have a level 30 cap, having previously had a level 60 cap. Why?
- The new character 'classes' are just the old classes but spliced into their constituent parts. So no longer can you carry pistols and a sword - it has to be a pistol class, or a sword class.
- Combat is a lot less fluid. Let's take the pistol class as an example - what has happened? You have to stand still and hold down the mouse button for 3 seconds to deal maximum damage? Why?
- Sometimes your mouse and keyboard presses do not register, meaning you don't shoot or use your skills on time.
- I always start my Van Helsing games on Hard mode. The first two games were punishing (but fair), but this is ludicrous. One of the first monsters you encounter can one-shot kill you. This isn't difficult, it is bonkers.
- Katarina's AI is still wonky. In the previous games you basically had to keep her in spectral form, because she would either aggro enemies you wanted to avoid, or else ignore enemies you wanted to aggro - and would die in a heartbeat. Still happening.
- The skill trees are even more cluttered than usual with useless skills and options that are frankly unclear.
+ The music is excellent, as ever.
+ The voice acting is great, as ever.
+ The new Protector class feels like something new to the franchise and looks great.
+ Random Sean Connery gnome.

I cannot currently recommend this to anyone new to the franchise, and if you are a veteran... my advice echoes that of other reviewers: wait until Neocore have patched the thing a little more.

Gutted.

In the meantime, boot up VH1 and remember when simpler was better :)

reviewText:
Update: Since some people are claiming I barely played the game I'll leave this here - http://steamcommunity.com/app/359900/discussions/1/617336568073325731/

I can only play the game in offline mode until Neocore decides to fix their game.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III is about Van Helsing's son, Abraham, and his ghostly companion. The third installment focused more on Katarina's backstory. We learned her origin story in this game and how she became a ghost. The story telling is about what you would expect if you've ever played a Van Helsing game then you'll be right at home with the witty dialogue and action combat.

The Good:

Gameplay:

If you've ever played an ARPG you'll know what to expect here. Tons of monsters, loot, and quest for you to do while you level up your character until you reach the level cap so you can farm for legendary gear or make a new class. It's no different here, but The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is different than your typical Diablo game. Van Helsing games have always had a mix of tower defense segments in them. Deathtrap is a good example of how they'll play out and if you don't know what Deathtrap is I encourage you to read my review here.

The major difference that sets The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III apart from it's predecessors are the six new character classes. I originally thought that these new classes would be available alongside the three we already had, but I was mistaken. The original three character classes from Van Helsing I and II are gone, but I'll go more into detail later on this review.

You'll obviously run into a lot of loot while you're out slaying monsters and you'll probably be making frequent trips back to your secret hideout or you can just give Lady Katarina all of your loot and let her sell it for you. This is a really great mechanic and I'm glad it's still present in the game.

Soundtrack:

The soundtrack here easily beats both Van Helsing I and II. The opening menu theme is beautiful and it really sets the tone of the game. Every track fits the stage it's on nicely and it really added to the experience for me. The only track I didn't like was the final boss one. It was just your average encounter music.

Six Character Classes:

As I stated above there are six character classes in The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III. All of them are vastly different than each other. I enjoyed my playthrough as an elementalist, but I do wish the skill tree was a lot deeper. In Van Helsing II we had over 20 magical skills to master over the course of our playthrough. In Van Helsing III we only have 8 and I beat the game only using two of them.

Story:

I was originally going to place this in the bad section of this review, but learning what happened to Lady Katarina and saving the world helped to place it in the positive section. There is nothing groundbreaking about the story here, but it gets the job done. I was disappointed in more than a few parts of the story, but I enjoyed the ending to the game. I would say it's a toss up between good and bad, but I enjoyed it more than I hated it.

In Van Helsing III your former ally, Prisoner 7, has betrayed you and is trying to convert the world back into the way it was in the past and to do that he's using the Ink to shape everything in his image. Van Helsing must save the day once again and get his revenge at the same time.

The Bad:

You Can't Import Your Old Characters:

This is probably my biggest problem with the game right now. All of that hard work I did going through both Van Helsing I and II was pointless. Why let us get attached to our old characters if you were never going to let us finish the trilogy with him?

The New Skill Tree Looks Nice, But It's Lacking:

There's no denying that the new skill tree in Van Helsing III looks better than it ever did, but we only have a fraction of the skills that we had in previous games. The only two spells that I used throughout my entire playthrough was my two lightning spells. The ice spells are useless and the only cool fire spell is the summon that you get, but what's the point of that when I one hit just about everything with my lightning?

The passive skill tree is still there, but it's also been gutted to hell and back. I don't understand why they decided to dumb the game down so much. Is it because it's going to the Xbox One?

Level 30 Cap:

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing II had a level 60 level cap. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III took it down to 30 for some reason. Why? Your guess is as good as mine. That's not the only thing that went down though. The game is way too easy. I started playing this morning and beat it a few hours later. It took me hours upon hours of gameplay to reach the level cap in Van Helsing I. It took me 7 hours to reach it in part III...

You Can't Buy Healing Potions Anymore:

Who thought it would be a good idea to take away our healing potions? I really want to know this so I can slap them in the face. Why would you take potions out of an ARPG? Instead of potions we get a single health/mana potion that takes an eternity to cooldown for another usage. Give me back my potions. I liked having over 100 of them.

No Neverending Story:

Every Van Helsing game had a Neverending Story mode. It's Van Helsing's version of a new game plus. It ramps up the difficulty and lets up play through the game as many times as we want. Why is it missing in here? The only thing I got after I completed the game was Scenario Mode, but I never really liked that mode.

Little To None Replayability:

Since there's no Neverending Story I don't really feel like jumping back in this game and I just started it today. I feel like Neocore Games ran out of funding for this game and just released it as is.

Van Helsing III Is Nearly Unplayable Right Now:

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III is filled with bugs. I had to figure out a way, by myself by the way, to enter the game. The developers had no idea what was causing my game crash. I can't even play this online right now because the game will only turn on in offline mode. I've walked on floors that were missing textures, and fell through the floor to my death a few times. There is a ton of missing dialogue. I could be talking to an npc that I'm actually interested in and the dialogue would just skip itself and go to the next line. This game was not ready to be released. It feels like a beta some times.

The Verdict:

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III right now is the weakest game in the trilogy. I have no idea what the devs were thinking when they stripped this game down and released it. I love the gameplay and I love Van Helsing, but I think I'll stick to parts 1 and 2 before I touch part 3 again. I'll wait until there's more content and I'll consider writing about this again one day, but I'm really disappointed that series ended this way.

6/10

reviewText:
Firstly, this is an EARLY review, written on the very first day of release.
[And then updated excessively week after, with some 70h of gameplay]

And to say this first, game is not FULLY completed - you can play story and scenarios up to level30. More features (Neverending Story, levels up to 60, probably a few completely new features). If this bothers you, wait a while, instead posting negative review.

Rather than continuing leveling from VH2 - (characters can be imported, but they don't keep levels and items, they DO keep glory points and are given Epic item at start), the game offers whooping SIX classes, some redesigned builds from earlier games, but some rather unique to the whole genre, as is strength-based-stealth class I play.

This, however, is a good thing, according to yours truly. Rather than continuing old imbalances, player is offered a 'clean' start, with a NUMBER of skills reduced, but CUSTOMIZATION possibility of each increased greatly. Some players complain about lowering number of skills - but, in my 11 years of everyday playing D2:LoD i used MAX 10 shortcut skills, and even then few were timed buffs. I found no problems with number of skills.

In my opinion, done much better than in... another aRPG game, where most of skill customization is plagued by one, dominant, choice. But, as said, this is an early review, and I'll update it soon... Anyhow, each skill is highly customizable, which would (probably) lead to many player-specific styles - you don't like how certain skill works? Customize! You like a skill above all the others? Boost it to the max! And suchfort...

Voice acting, graphics and humour - a trait really rare in the genre - is on very high level, as in previous two games. Gameplay is intensive and diverse for each class.

[UPDATE]Itemization:
Firstly, most of item slots are unique to a class. Some are not (rings, and some other), so there won't be instant-godlike characters, but rather somewhat 'boosted' ones, with shared item-slots, gold and essences, which is more fair and challenging, yet not completely overpowered.

Secondly, crafting items to be exactly to needed specification is no more. Rares can be enchanted, filled with essences and have ONE affix rerolled (as many times as gold permits, though price increases every time). This is a fine addition in my book, and fully developing character to be able to play on high difficulties and gameplay worth WON'T be a 5-6h - unless you plan to speed-run casual or normal, in case when you got what you deserved.

Casual players, playing with friends, also needn't to worry - following story, exploring maps and finding secrets and easter eggs will take over 20h of gameplay for sure. If you want to do this with different characters, more.

Sets are improved, from being useless but so hard to get in VH2. They could use more buff, as well as some Epics I found, and I believe it will be done in one of next patches. Probably more will be added, VH2 had a free patch that added 120+ Epic and Godlike items.

Multiplayer - well, I don't know about it - according to developers, a new generation of netcode is implemented, so MP problems plaguing first two games should be worked out. I can neither confirm nor deny this yet.

PvP - same applied.

Endgame:
UPDATED: As said above, finished version WILL have 60 levels and Neverending Story. Current version 1.0.2 has Story Mode (up to level30) and scenarios, which are randomly created adventures consisting of three mandatory and three bonus maps, each of which require a random victory condition (eliminate main boss, collect loot from the special chest, catch Domovoys - hilarious on later levels, and so on). When the Neverending Story, a mode that will be supposedly unfinishable, is added, scenarios will serve the purpose of training characters (Glory) and farming gold (upgrade items) and items (increased droprates) to equip character better.

I know this functions, since all my playhours were with same character :)

Every now and then, a-bit-better-rare drops, then I spend some money to improve it. Improving items is luck dependent - if it fails and gives bad affix, it can be rerolled, but there is everincresing price of that service. To put simply, there is no more one hundred click on reroll until exact affix is rolled. Perhaps if the game let me import my hundred zillion billions from VH2 :) but, fortunately, it didn't.

So, I EXPECT farm more satisfying endgame, a number of reasons led me to this. But currently, it's just as said above, farming has a good timing between better item is found and it's rather promising.

Mandatory pizza comparison:
For a value of one, perhaps two, player will get rich (and funny) storyline, where quests, even if not unique, have a genre-parody value... C'mon, everyone has killed 8 pigs, then 10 pigs, and quest can't get dumber than that. Inhere, however, even when such a quest exist, it contains a well measured quantity of biting-satire, which makes it far less boring, or even funny to do... Whatabout pizza? Well, for a price of 1-2, you'll get a game that will entertain you for at least 20 times than pizzas would, and possibly much more so.

Conclusion:
The game is of near-AAA quality, and for a price several times lower. Some things, like cultural references and jokes, are unique to the rather bleak (or at its best - gloomy and depressing) genre atmosphere.

Should you buy it? If you like aRPG in general, but value unusual storyline, humorous dialogues and  story-driven game - YES! If you expect game that works absolutely flawless (mind you, after few hours of gameplay - no bugs observed) - probably 'yes', especially if you played that other AAA aRPGs, which failed to deliver at the launch...

UPDATED: If you want completely finished, polished, bugless game - you should wait some more time, it won't take long now.

Rather WAIT, than buy it and then whine and post negative reviews advising players not to buy it... This is *mine* review, and it contains what I think is objective and how *I* feel about the game. If it misled you into buying, rate it unhelpful, that's why the option is.

But if *you* wrote own negative review after 0.2h of play, and now are going around lowering positive reviews ratings - rather mature thing to do, you should be proud - one who does that will recognize himself, though there are others, too - it kinda breaks whole point of reviews. But you don't care about it, anyway.

Demo:
There also should be a free-demo, I've been told, if so - download and decide for yourself. According to me, an aRPG veteran, this is one of the best games in the genre and absolutely worth the bargain price. Compare it to the D3, TL2, PoE, GD? I *could* do it, but why so? This game is *different* in atmosphere, and close to original D2, from which all of the above derived.

EDIT: as a answer to FREDDY, in my opinion games should be played in order - if for nothing else, than for rich and high-quality storyline - from what I've heard, writer is an publisher author and it shows well - a deep and rich lore, a developing story - it looks much lighter and simpler in the VH1, but gets more grim later, with the part 1 story-revisited (to a point) from a quite different angle in VH3... If you want just one, then VH2 is more feature-rich and sports leveling up to lvl60 - and then, there is where Prisoner7 appears, whose voice-acting is nothing short of amazing!

At the end, a temporary conclusion:
If you're in situation to, support indie gaming companies who make quality games. I do it - though I was a beta-tester and therefore got the previous games for free, I still contributed financially. I'm not a rich person, but I could afford to (avoid couple of pizzas and) actually *pay* for every NeoCore game so far - developing doesn't come free and one should support what one loves, or there will be none in the future.

Enough said, best of luck!

I really enjoyed this game, it's a solid ARPG and a lot of fun, but why don't I recommend it? As a big fan of the series since the first game, I can't help but be majorly disappointed.

The jump from Van Helsing 1 to Van Helsing 2 was pretty big. You got another large and interesting story, the level cap was doubled and the skill tree was also double. But it seems like they've taken all that back out for this installment.

The story is painfully short and feels rushed, the final boss fight is a joke and an absolute pushover, the level cap has been halved back down to 30, and the skill tree has also been dramatically reduced to a tree that's even small than the one in the original game. They try to make up for the small skill trees and low level cap by having 6 character classes instead of 3 but that opens up another problem.
The 3 original classes are gone meaning, as most other fans of the series have pointed out, no character import.
As far as I can tell, the original 3 are still there in spirit. The Hunter now being the Bounty Hunter, Arcane Mechanic now being the Constructor, and the Thaumaturge now being the Elementalist. But these classes have been changed and reduced down so much that they're just shells of their former selves.

Another thing that got to me a bit is the lack of New Game+. This is more of a personal thing to me but when I finish the game, I like to go back to the start with my high level character, and play through again on a higher difficulty like you can do in Titan Quest and Dark Souls for example.

But, does this game do anything right?

Actually yes. The gameplay itself is very enjoyable. It's a solid ARPG, it's challenging in places and there's plenty of little side areas to explore and secrets to find. The graphics are pretty and the Elementalist's skills are especially flashy! (I like pretty lights!)

Conclusion:
A fun game, but feels more of an addon to Van Helsing 2 with it's short story, reduced level cap and reduced skill trees. It does have some plus sides but as of now (26/05/2015) I can't recommend it.
I have heard that the devs will continue to add free content updates in the future, so I may come back to this review then and my opinion may change.

Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Note: this review is written for players of the previous two installments. If you are a new player to the franchise, I would NOT start here. Play the previous two and, if you enjoy them, you might want to risk the third game just to complete the story.

I like a lot of what they did with the mechanics and streamlining. No need to collect potions or split the stack and hand some to Katarina, you both have infinite potions on (I believe) the same cooldown from the previous games. The classes are more focused to particular playstyles, so you don't waste a skill points picking up a single rank of a skill you will never use just so you can get to the stuff you want. Several of the classes possess unusual gameplay mechanics (such as the Protector's block skill) that make them unique, rather than Class A just increasing a different set of numbers than Class B. Every class has every skill available from the get go rather than having to gain 20 levels and traverse a skill tree to make your build.

On the other hand, some of it feels really shoddy. Each class has a much clearer focus than in the previous games and they could have used that to make the skills deeper and more rewarding, but instead they just tacked on two more passive upgrades per skill and called it a day. Sending your officers out on missions becomes mostly luck-based later in the game, as the mission descriptions are not as clear and your soldier effectiveness is much harder to maintain; I tried to make logical choices, but my officers failed almost every mission from midgame onwards. Tricks were removed entirely, cutting out one of several major features meant to allow customization. The level caps are insultingly low (30 levels for Van Helsing, 10 reputation ranks, and 25 levels for Katarina) and easily reached before the end of a single playthrough on Normal.

The story is rushed. They hint at some interesting lore, but ultimately the delivery falls flat. It is cool to learn about Katarina's past, but it comes so quickly over the course of a single (short) act that there is no time to really explore it or allow much interplay between Van Helsing and Katarina. The ending, especially, is anti-climactic. The big bad goes out with a whimper instead of a bang.

It's not just the story that is hurried, either. Equipment upgrades are so frequent that the few unique/set items you find are unlikely to last more than a few minutes. This also means enchanting and essences, the other major customization features in the previous two games, are a hassle at best and detrimental at worst, encouraging you to waste money on rapidly obsoleted equipment. Your chimera still has slots for summoning candles in the UI, but there are no candles in the game, and even if there were, there are no Tricks so you have no way to summon him anyway. Katarina has all of her old skills, but with only 25 levels, she can't pick up the final two points of her final tier skills because she has to be 26 and 27 for the 7th and 8th points, respectively. The game doesn't feel polished at all.

I am apparently lucky and had a bug-free playthrough. The only thing that felt like a bug was when I encountered a few monsters (including the final boss) that had immunity to every damage type. I don't know if there is a trick to fighting them or not, but Katarina can damage them for whatever reason and I played a Protector, so I tanked them and let her take care of the heavy lifting.

Overall, this is a pretty big step down from the previous two installments. I loved the previous two games, but I can't recommend this one. If you really must finish the story, go ahead and buy it. I recommend tempering your enthusiasm, though, so hopefully you won't be as disappointed as I was.

reviewText:
The dungeon crawling role-playing game genre has always been dominated by Blizzard's Diablo series but this doesn't mean that other, smaller studios have given up on the market. Quite the opposite, as there's been stiff competition from the likes of Torchlight and an even smaller experience, in the form of The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, coming from Hungarian studio Neocore.
After delighting plenty of fans with the first two installments in the series, the developer's back with The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III, which continues the story, adds quite six all-new classes, and continues to refine the gameplay mechanics from its predecessors. At the same time, however, it does make a few sacrifices, as veterans can't import their old characters and the level cap has been lowered to 30.
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III picks up from where its predecessor left off, continuing the story by focusing on what Prisoner Seven plans for the world of Borgovia, as well as on the origins of Katarina, Van Helsing's ghostly companion. The plot is pretty interesting but what really elevates it is the fun dialog that retains the wit and sarcasm from past entries and doesn't even require knowledge of previous games to enjoy. There are also plenty of hilarious sequences involving monsters and other such things, offering a change of pace from the somber things you'll see throughout the rest of the plot.There are a few interesting twists and turns but some you can smell from a mile away. Even so, especially for veterans, the plot is pretty enjoyable. In case this is your first Van Helsing experience, while you certainly take greater pleasure if you've gone through past titles, you'll still be brought up to speed through cinematic sequences and diary entries.
In terms of gameplay The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III brings a few controversial changes over its predecessors. While it's still a pretty good dungeon crawling RPG experience, Neocore has made some sweeping modifications to a few mechanics, not to mention its classes and skill trees.
Gone are the three main classes from past games and in are six all-new ones that offer some pretty varied experiences. For melee enthusiasts, there are two wildly different classes. The hulking Protector wields a giant flail and a shield, similar to Diablo 3's Crusader, but can actually use the shield in combat to block damage, instead of it acting as a passive damage reduction. The Umbralist is a swift dual-wielding rogue that uses twin blades to inflict plenty of damage.
Those who prefer shooting from afar can pick from the other four classes. The Elementalist feels like the traditional Wizard from Diablo 3, for example, but his flashy abilities bring plenty of style. The Phlogistoneer is certainly the most intriguing in terms of visual style, unleashing fire, rockets, and other projects at foes, while relying on a shield to protect himself in close quarters.
The Bounty Hunter relies on guns to do the damage, so don't expect him to act like the Hunter class from past games. Last but not least, there's the Constructor, who relies on building gadgets and machines to do the dirty work for him. In combination with Katarina, who can engage enemies in melee or ranged forms, you can take a hands-off approach to combat.
All the classes are pretty varied but the fact that they can only be leveled up to a cap of 30, after Van Helsing II's 60 limit, does put a hamper on your fun. The skill trees are pretty varied but they require quite a lot of study and experimentation before you can really master them. Throw in the same rather complex interface that hides things away with buttons, tabs, and panels, and you'll need to invest a bit of time before you can really figure things out. The other dungeon crawling mechanics, such as the inventory or the loot systems are still quite good, offering plenty of different gear and options for your different classes.
Besides the regular dungeon crawling mechanics, you can still engage in Tower Defense missions, which offer some pretty interesting challenges, but also in mini-games that task you with managing your forces and your Chimera by sending them on missions in exchange for loot and other rewards.
Unfortunately, you can no longer go through the game via its Endless Story mode, which acted as a sort of New Game +, so there aren't a lot of reasons to replay it. There is a Scenario mode that allows you to try and complete certain situations in the fastest time possible, so players are encouraged to keep coming back to the RPG.
The level design is very good, managing to offer plenty of different environments to explore, including hidden nook, crannies, and Easter Eggs that reward thorough players.
Like previous titles, Van Helsing III offers an online cooperative and a competitive mode. Up to four players can go through the story together while up to eight can go up against one another in a test of skill and gear. The multiplayer mode handles relatively well but matchmaking is a bit lengthy, especially during certain time intervals. Even so, it's pretty fun and a nice diversion over the regular campaign.
In terms of graphics, Van Helsing III retains the style employed by its predecessors and, while it's not that detailed or pretty to the eye, it's still fairly good and manages to keep things fresh for an isometric dungeon crawler. Enemies in particular are varied and well-designed.
The soundtrack is also pretty good but some of the audio taunts and effects used by certain enemies can wear on your nerves. The voice acting is great, particularly when it comes to Katarina, which manages to deliver her witty remarks very well.
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III is a good game but it might not exactly delight all of its players. Yes, it's a pity that players can't import their characters and classes but the new ones are quite varied, even if they can only reach level 30. For such a low price, Neocore's RPG is a great investment.

reviewText:
Firstly, about the series in general:

I *love* this series.  I'm not an action RPG expert, but after having sunk over 80+ hours into Diablo 3 and expansion, 30+ hours into Torchlight/Torchlight 2, and a little bit into Grim Dawn and Path of Exile, I still find the Van Helsing series my favorite ARPG.  Yes, better than the mighty D3.  Hands down.

In terms of mechanics, the game is solid.   Easy to play, satisfying combat, and even a whole major tower defence subgame!  The developers have distilled the essense of an RPG and captured it precisely.   It's also very pretty; hand crafted dungeons are more interesting than the random generated crossword puzzles of certain other ARPGs.   Also: gamepad support for you TV players!

In terms of narrative ... love it.  The gothic steampunk world is dark and interesting (and most importantly, not a cliche).  The dialog between the characters is amusing without ever getting tiresome - and the humorous bits (and pop culture references) are genuinely funny.    Whomever did the North American localization for Neocore - you sir/m'aam did an amazing job.   There isn't too much dialog, (never too far from the action), and I was always interested in seeing what happened next.  It's also decently voice acted, too.  (Especially Katarina...actress totally nails the psychotic haughty eastern european diva)

Now, having said that, let's focus on this particular chapter, the third and final one.

Flat out ... it's a bit of a step backwards.  As much as I love the series, this one isn't quite as good as the second one (or even the first).  There's a low level cap, the skill system has been changed a bit (for the worse), there are no character imports - and the game just feels shorter than the previous games in the series.   The loot drops were much stingier, and though I didn't encounter any of the uncompletable quest" bugs people have written about
date:
I did suffer frequent crashes to the desktop - which was exacerbated by a painfully long load time.

Is it still a hell of a good time?  Yes.   Is it the weakest in the trilogy?  Sadly yes.

But here's the thing: if you've played the other two in the series (which you probably have)

I feel Van Helsing III has the best balance for the Constructor tower defense play style compared to any other games I've tried similar classes as I feel the towers and gun skills are equals none overpowering the other nor being to weak to bother with.  If you enjoy such classes (Dungeon Defenders, Rocket Raccoon in Marvel Heroes, or Sentry play in Diablo 3) then I expect you'll really enjoy this class.
The game does a wonderful job of keeping leveling up exciting and rapid.  So far I feel in need of the level up and am happy enough with the results.  It's easy to sink hours into this game in a single sitting, wanting to try out another skill or level them up.  Additionally the environments and enemies have continued to stay fresh.
If you do get in a rut you can always return to your base and partake in other meta games like tower of defense and sending minions out on jobs for loot.
The story doesn't have me overly excited but it's at least been enough to keep me following it versus ignoring dialog.  It's a surprise considering the low price,that very nearly all the dialog is spoken.  Then there's a journal if you want to read further into the game's world.
I tired of the original Van Helsing for a mere 7 hours (enjoyed it for the first few hours) getting bored with what seemed to be a constant battle tactic of being forced to fight a horde of enemies over and over without enough variety in the repetition and lost interest after checking out various sword/gun skills.  I skipped VH2, VH3 has many classes to chose from which all sound vastly different to play so surely you'll find something you enjoy in this final episode.  Unless you play ARPGs for story there is no need to play VH1 and/or VH2 prior to this one.  It's improved in it's mechanics even though most fights are fighting groups of enemies they vary much more in speed/approach and aren't in such huge horde numbers and often there will be 1 different powerful enemy by itself or mixed in to groups of 2 other types of enemies.  It's got more variety in the combat, you aren't going to have great success repeating exact same combos each attack, you have to vary it based on terrain and enemy placements (at least for Constructor class).
The Loot isn't as exciting as Diablo 3 Loot 2.0, but it's plenty competent for a $15 game.
If you are looking for a fun cheap ARPG this is a great value.

reviewText:
This is a weak recommendation, mostly for people who want to see how the story ends, or if you want to receive the Final Cut edition for free next month.

This is the final installment of the Van Helsing series, and if you had hoped it would end on a high note you'll be disappointed. VH3 is definitely a downgrade over the previous games, the biggest regression being the skill system, it has been dumbed-down by removing many skills and changing others, this leaves you with very little choice when it comes to creating your build. The toughest decision you'll have to make is which of the skills you'll max out first, as you'll end up maxing out most of them by the end anyway. Another major issue with the game is simply the classes aren't fun to play, the skills are boring, the skill trees are bland and I honestly felt only two of the six classes were enjoyable enough to finish the game with.

If you can get past the boring classes and restrictive skill system another backtrack from previous games is the loot, much like in VH1 you will rarely find any legendary items, by the end of my play-through I only had two equipped. In VH2 this was fixed and the loot progression was great, I was regularly finding interesting, build changing legendaries and I have no idea why they went back on this in VH3.

Now if you can look past the bad, underneath it's the same old Van Helsing, so if you enjoyed the first two games you'll probably enjoy this one too, just not as much as the previous entries. The solid voice work and humor once again carries the game and makes you forgive certain downfalls, and if you want to see how the story ends I would suggest picking the game up when it's 50 - 75% off as it's not worth full price. That being said, if you own all the Van Helsing games you will be entitled to the Final Cut edition for free which is releasing next month, it's basically all three games combined and improved (although we're not sure how, but they have said they're overhauling the skill system which was absolutely necessary IMO). My advice would be to wait and play the Final Cut edition, instead of playing VH3 as a standalone game.

I set something in motion. That's never a good thing.
— Van Helsing

Early in the game, while walking through a forest, Van Helsing and Katarina come across a gigantic crystal thingy just sitting there, doing nothing. Van Helsing is nervous. Katarina, curious. “Hit it, Van Helsing,” she says. I had the option to do as she asked, or refuse. Obligingly, curious myself, I took a shot at it. Three monsters promptly spawned and, yowling, I ran off to a safe distance from which to shoot at them. When I was done, Katarina goes, “That was exciting! Hit it again!”

Four, perhaps six times, I hit it, alternately spawning monsters and items. One of the spawns was some manner of rabid bunny. Each time, Katarina was equally excited. And I was cracking up behind the keyboard.

The third and final installment of the Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing trilogy, this hack-n-slash turned out to be a heck of a lot more fun than I had imagined. It only took ten, maybe fifteen minutes for me to get into the game – because Van Helsing offers one thing that a lot of games try at, but miss – humour.

As much as I love these games, this was a bit of a disappointment. I'd recommend it, as the game was fun, but whether I'd recommend it at full price I don't know.

I started to get a bit worried about this game before I even started it. With VH2, there were pre-orders, you could get extras, and it felt like we could be much more involved. That wasn't the case with VH3. No pre-order, no bonuses, no benefits for those of us who owned the first two games in the series.

The Good:

The new classes are a lot of fun - I played through as the Protector and really enjoyed it. Given that these games are a bit samey, I don't think I'll play through it again as a different class.

The Bad:

I essentially see Neocore as an indie outfit, so they can be forgiven for some replication - but this is essentially exactly the same game with new maps and new classes.

The Tower Defence elements have been stripped right back. It only occurs three times and it didn't feel nearly as fun as it did previously. In the last one, one of the traps didn't actually work - you couldn't even place it. (I forget the name of it, but it's the cage that houses the werewolf-type creatures).

Buggy. Not only the trap mentioned above, but some of Katriana's skills didn't even seem to do anything.

Too easy. I played on the second-hardest setting (not sure why, usually go for the hardest settings but maybe I'm getting old!) and there was no challenge to the game. The Protector was such a powerful class that I just steamrolled everything, including the final boss, who barely took me below 100% health.

Loot. The loot was just a bit uninspired. I just kept swapping between very slightly better versions of each item. The only upgrades I ever seemed to get were from the shop. Drops were terrible. I didn't get one item better than rare, and none of the items had any interesting effects to them.

The So So:

The skill trees. I didn't like skill trees from VH2. There were too many skills, most of which were useless once you got the better versions. It didn't have the same kind of progressive feel of games like Diablo 2. In that regard, the trees in VH3 are better - but perhaps they've gone too far in the other direction. I only had four skills for the entire game. The other two were pointless. More to the point, those were the only skills available at all - there was no choice between play styles or using one skill over another.

Having read my review, I'm not sure why I'm recommending the game - but even with its flaws, it's still better than a lot of games out there. It might be samey, but at least it's samey as compared to great games.

I'm giving this a positive, mostly because I loved the first two games, and it seems such a shame that the third one felt only half-baked. The first one was a stellar entry for the genre, but the second felt a little bit of a step down, and the third which I've just finished playing was mediocre in comparison.

While the addition of the new classes was interesting, and the music was absolutely fantastic, the fact that I couldn't import my characters and items from the second was frustrating to say the least. I carried on grinding after the story ending in VH2 to get all the godlike items, and amassed a fortune, only to find VH3 WOULDN'T LET ME CARRY A SINGLE ONE OVER! ARRRRGGGGGH.

Next, what was with the loot? VH1 and VH2 let me indulge in my love of hoarding loot, with great sets or epic items being dropped. Perhaps it was just my game, but not a single set item showed up, and I had all of 2 special items. It was nice however that Katarina had her own stuff at last, rather than things I didn't want anymore.

Also, why such a low level cap?! Yes the leveling in this game has been restructured and a bit more freeing, but the level cap for my character and Katarina was just too low.

I also encountered some frustration with the final boss fight, not loading at all when trying to get in, not connecting to my co-op buddy, crashing, and then when I finally made it back in, doing some awful things with the camera so I couldn't see what I was hitting.

And what happened to the LAN? That suddenly disappeared which makes no sense at all.

Finally, this franchise has been great with all of its pop culture references, dealt out with some style and wit. Unfortunately, it felt as if the game was rushed out without putting that much of this in, so I quite missed these.
Overall, this might sound like a bad game, but honestly, it's not. It's just that in comparison to the other two, it feels more acceptable, rather than good. What I can't complain about however is the price point. It's a decent enough game for the price, £11.99. It just didn't feel like a fitting finale for what has been a great franchise overall.

I'd say buy this to support this independent developer, but for a game you can really enjoy, VH1 and VH2 are your best bets.

reviewText:
With the Final Cut edition of the entire trilogy out soon, I am just in the nick of time to write a Van Helsing review. Despite the nitpicks of other players, this is a solid ARPG. As can be said of any ARPG, they are a treadmill, and a time waster. And this is where Van Helsing III falls short. There is a low level cap. About 30.

Secondly, your beastie shares the same level cap. Game was over before I knew it. BAM! Levelling was consistent thereout. The loot system was solid. Combat felt great! The skilltree? Underrated. Picking passives is awesome. It means your skills never lose their utility, but unlock different variables and special abilities as they go.

Powering up your abilities detracted from the whole game, as time spent waiting is time I'd rather spend killing. It seemed rather superfluous to the whole system, as well. Was it fun? Yes. Does it beat Path of Exile and the competition? It stands alongside. Proudly, in this reviewers estimation.

I'd really like to praise the devs in making old skills feel new again. As expected, this is a narrative-driven Diablo, and there are bugs. The main problems are in consistency, as a treadmill should not end so briefly; and the endgame felt abrupt. The new classes, however, really are where this game shines. I played a stealth character this time through, and was not disappointed. There are worse ways of spending ones hours. Really.

Nor am I going to be an apologist for this game. It is great. I would give it a solid 7/10.

Pros:
-Fun
-Consistent levelling
-Basically whatever can be praised about any ARPG
-Passives Skilltree

Cons:
-Low levelling cap
-Low beastie levelling cap
-Low Katarina levelling cap
-Game was over before I knew it.
-Game does not explain that picking passive gifts is permanent

A solid $20. I'm glad I threw down on this game. Apparently, it's not everyone's cup of tea. Better to watch a gameplay walkthrough, then decide for yourself. In contrary to public opinion, I am going to rate it up, as I feel it deserves a higher rating, and is a solid release on its own ground.

I also found a few bugs, though I hope this has been cleared up by now. Despite my nitpicks and annoyances above, give this game a go. It is nothing revolutionary, it won't reinvent the wheel, but it is solid entertainment for a good 20 hours; which is $1/hour. Cheap, for what ye receiveth!

You know… in all honesty I’ve still got a review for the first game in the series as a draft just chilling on the site. I feel kind of bad that I never put it up… or finished it. On the other hand, it was pretty stinking awesome! Now the third installment of the game is out and it’s also blowing my mind. A built-in tank class (Protector)? Yes please!

So this takes place after the second game in which you stopped a big civil war, but the world is never truly fixed is it? No… not if we need more games in a franchise it’s not! And luckily it’s not over yet since they gave me a giant mech to play with this time. I’m a bigger fan of the thought of playing a tank (the Protector class), but not this time. I’ve figured out that class enough to know that it’s not crazy-super-tanky, it’s the regular type. It’s cool, but with my playstyle, it just wasn’t working out. Now the guy pictured above is where it’s at! He’s not a tank, but what do you need to tank when all the enemies are already exploded? Nothing really. This guy shoots out a ton of rockets and then mops up with a flamethrower! I don’t care what you think about this game, this class is fun!

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III (gosh that’s a keyboard full… well just call it Van Helsing III from here) controls much the same as in the (I assume since I haven’t played the second one yet) much like the earlier two titles. It uses the typical ARPG click to attack fest with hotkeys for select moves. It still works well here. There isn’t as much funky “can’t get there from here” as I experienced in the first game so the path-finding seems to be better. That did kind of drive me nuts in Van Helsing I. The only thing that bothers me is when loot drops off a cliff or behind something and I couldn’t get it. Now… I was in a giant suit of armor and I’m not that small, I get it, but why couldn’t my smarty-pants ghost buddy Katarina pick it up? She’s a ghost… it’s just physics! Or science… or ghost physcience… or whatever you want to call it where she can go nab my loot for me when it falls behind something she should be able to phase through. Luckily, this only happened twice or so in my 16-ish hours of playing.

There are, once again, skill trees to explore and different options to level up and all that jazz. There aren’t so many that it’s overwhelming, but there are plenty of options that will make you salivate since you’ll want them all if you’re anything like me. One look at the trees after about twenty minutes of play and I can usually map out where I want to go. I’m a big fan of moves that go boom and stuff, oh and feeling awesome. I love using the rocket move solely and the ability to strengthen them and add more rockets to your salvo just makes me happy. I think I would have loved a bit more destructible environments, but I don’t need that in every game… but it would have been neat.

The mini game where you play tower defense is back. While not my favorite part of the game, it is pretty cool. I do enjoy the fact that you can run around with your character and help your turrets and traps with all the nifty moves you’ve leveled up in the main game. (There’s an achievement for not helping though… jerks. Don’t they understand I’ve got rockets that need to go boom?) Plopping turrets and flame units and a few spike traps helps to kill the baddies before they reach your spherical ball of funkiness. Don’t let them touch the funk! It’s not the greatest tower defense, but it’s a neat addition to the game (again) and is a good way to break of up the “monotony” of stabbing and blowing things up by… stabbing and blowing things up… in a confined area.

There is also a way to manage the resistance (that I believe was in the second game). I’m not sure if it’s improved from the second game, but it was interesting. Having completed a few missions in it I can honestly say… I’m not sure what the point of it completely is, but it’s neat to have that part of the story be fleshed out some more. It’s kind of like it’s telling you that there is more going on in the world than just what you are doing. As if the world would stop if/when you left your base. While it may not be amazing, I think it makes the game a bit more full and better for having it in. That and the tower defense really just add to the experience.

In Van Helsing III you are starting to unravel the story behind Katarina and it’s pretty interesting. It’s not super gripping, but it’s one of those things that you’re glad you learned the back-story even if it wasn’t life-changing. The banter back and forth between Van Helsing and her is still good as good as it was in the original and will still give you a few chuckles throughout the game (maybe not when they are being all serious though… nah, there’s still humor there about ponies and such). All good things must come to an end and stuff, but I’ve enjoyed the series and I’m excited to see what else NeocoreGames has for me later on down the road.

Score: Gewd.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing III doesn’t go above and beyond so much so that it feels completely different from the first game. There are improvements and new things to do in Van Helsing III, but nothing jumps out as “holy crap amazingly different”. Which isn’t to say it’s a bad thing. Having loved the fist installment and I’ll probably enjoy the second when I get around to it with my bud, more of the same good quality game is just fine with me especially when they continue on from themselves to tell a fun story that I want to finish. Van Helsing III is a great title to play solo or with buds. If you’re interested in this game, I’d highly recommend picking the other two up as well as the story does lead from one to the next. You don’t need to play them, but there will be spoilers to be had and I know that bothers some people.

The potions do still exist in the code, and I was able to get the monsters to drop them by changing some config files. But, they did not do anything.

Overall, this game only took a few hours and most of my time was spent afterwards messing with the game files.

I don't feel ripped off, but the game does not feel finished. Many bugs, crashes, and UI problems should not exist in a released game.

And if you are thinking about using a controller, do yourself a favor and don't. The game is almost unplayable because of the difficult to control UI when using a controller. Switching to keyboard and mouse makes it feel like a completely different game.

reviewText:
Writing this after four hours of play, I do feel I can recommend this game,  but with some BIG qualifiers. This iteration of the series is very different in a lot of ways from the first two, though it plays a bit more like VH1 to me, which is my preference.

On the plus side, like its predecessors it's a very good-looking game with excellent voice acting and characterization--Van Helsing and Katerina are as entertaining as ever, and the quests are imaginative and fun in terms of keeping you both mentally and physically occupied. The pace seems less frenetic, and the locations are more like those in VH1, open and interesting, less jammed with meaningless  explosions and low level trash mobs every two feet and far less confusing than the opening of VH2.

I personally have not found it buggy, but there *are* all kinds of annoyances, like almost no loot drops (on Hard difficulty) long cooldowns on potions, a slow level process and reinstatement of the original level 30 cap, not to mention  the ability of offscreen enemies to attack and wipe you out when you can't see or target them, etc. I also wish the option to bring in your old character and or at least play the old classes was here- I miss my vanilla ranged hunter and thaumaturge. The 6 new classes with just a few skills each are rather disappointing after the first two games and their intricate skill trees, more flashy than really interesting to develop, kind of style over substance, and the VERY stingy skill point allocations mean that you generally stick with what skills you start with because there's no room to experiment with a new skill.  (Gold to re-spec, and essences to enchant are  also much scarcer so far than the first two games in my experience.)

So, is this a perfect game? Not in the least. But it is an entertaining and interesting seven or eight hours of solid casual arpg play, and hopefully will be improved and fleshed out a bit more if all three games are integrated in the future. I recommend waiting a bit for a few patches if you have doubts, or sticking with the first two games for now if importing your character is important to you. For the price, as some have said, you get what you pay for here, and not much beyond that, but I don't in any way feel ripped off, especially if there are truly plans to merge the three games and hopefully address some of the issues above.

The game gets a lot of hate for only one reason: you can't import your character from the previous games. While it's a pretty big deal to be honest, VHIII is still the same Van Helsing game we loved.

It has some negatives like the difficulty is not balanced: hard is super easy, but the difficulty above that is punishingly difficult (I'm saying coz I'm not a regular arpg gamer). The game has less side quests and puzzles than the previous installments which makes the game more grindy which is not a good thing. It doesn't bring new elements to the series either.

But it has some good things as well. The story is more enjoyable than the previous games, Katerina's side story is particularly well written. The ending is satisfying unlike some other franchizes. The artstyle of the areas is the best in this episode, and also the level design is quiet good. I enjoyed the boss fights as well. They bring some freshness to the usual game play.
The soundtrack is also the best here.

Overall is a fun and solid closure of the series. If you enjoyed the previous games and you can live with the fact that you need to start a new character you will enjoy this game.
If you were not a fan of the previous episodes, there is no reason for you to buy this.
If you are a newcomer, play the first game which is the most original and complete experience of the series. VHII and III are only expansions after all, not standalone new games.

So far not so good, glitchy, new classes are very unbalanced, and instead to adding some stuff like the 2nd one did, they removed some (skill tree is simplified, no potions etc.). Only good thing is that engine is far better optimised this time (loadings are noticeably faster).

In general it just feels far less inspired and instead of pushing for the best at end of trilogy it's the worst so far.

I mean it's not a bad game, but at this point it is 6.5/10.

ADVICE: Wait for patches and then play the game.

Ohh, and yeah. They put game at regular price, I bought it. Then they added a -10% promotion, and a bit later -20% which is a shame cause this is a good game for 8.79, but not more.

As a big fan of 1 and 2, this one has a NO from me.
